request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Confidential Medical Records
Mail completed form to Privacy Office

forms.document_type: Request for amendment of protected health information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients download a generic HIPAA authorization form from the Medical Records page, print and handwrite all fields, and mail or deliver it; MyChart is listed as a delivery option and may also support requests.

red_flags: Electronic delivery risk-shifting language requires patients to assume 'all consequences, losses and damages' for receiving records electronically, potentially discouraging digital access
Purpose field (Section 5h) may create impression that patients must justify their access, which is not required under HIPAA § 164.524 for patient self-access
bright_spots: Trilingual form availability (English, Spanish, Haitian Creole) — uncommon and reflects South Florida community needs
Five delivery methods including e-Delivery and MyChart alongside traditional options
Two-business-day processing commitment, far faster than the HIPAA-allowed 30-day window
Granular record type selection with ~15 specific categories and an Abstract shortcut option

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available on the main website navigation (Patients & Visitors > Medical Records) with direct PDF download, no login/CAPTCHA/bot blocking, and all language versions grouped on one page.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: The PDF has a text layer and is digitally authored but has zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite completion; MyChart is listed as a delivery option providing a potential digital alternative, but the primary form workflow requires paper; no explicit fax or email submission pathway for the form itself.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: The form has a logical 5-section numbered structure with granular record type options, but the acknowledgment statements (5a-5h) are dense legal text, the English PDF is bloated at 2.45 MB with garbled hidden template content, and a typo appears in the Creole version.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form but must navigate a generic third-party authorization design — the recipient field, purpose statement, and marketing compensation section are irrelevant for self-access, and the form does not reference HIPAA Right of Access, despite offering patient-friendly delivery options.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Includes revocation rights, non-conditioning statement, and proper sensitive-information disclosure; minor ambiguities include the purpose field and electronic delivery risk-shifting language, but no requirements that would materially impede patient access.

overall.summary: Memorial Healthcare System excels at findability and offers notable patient-friendly features (trilingual forms, fast processing, multiple delivery methods) but is held back by a non-fillable, generic authorization form that doesn't distinguish patient self-access from third-party release.
